elements.content: We present a new family of Ag­(I) complexes bearing calixarene-based tetraethynide ligands, namely, [Ag12(L1)2­·(CH3CN)4­·(NO3)4]­·2H2O (1), [Ag4L1­·(AgCF3CO2)4­·(CH3OH)] (2), [Ag4L2·(AgCF3CO2)4]­·H2O (3), and [Ag4L3­·(AgCF3CO2)4]­·0.75CH3COCH3 (4), which were obtained from the reaction of newly synthesized tetraethynyl functionalized resorcin[4]­arenes with silver­(I) salts. Complex 1 features a 4/m assembly comprising a Ag12 cage sandwiched by two bowl-shaped resorcin[4]­arene tetraethynides, while 2–4 exhibit similar silver­(I) chain structures each stabilized by an alternate attachment of bowl-shaped resorcin[4]­arene tetraethynide units. This work provides the successful example of the use of calixarene-based ligands for the construction of multinuclear silver­(I)–ethynide supramolecular frameworks.

Complex 1 features a 4/m assembly comprising a Ag12 cage sandwiched by two bowl-shaped resorcin[4]arene tetraethynides, while 2-4 exhibit similar silver(I) chain structures each stabilized by an alternate attachment of bowl-shaped resorcin[4]arene tetraethynide units. This work provides the successful example of the use of calixarene-based ligands for the construction of multinuclear silver(I)-ethynide supramolecular frameworks.

elements.content: A new family of silver­(I) tetra−ethynide complexes exhibiting a remarkable sandwich Ag12 cage and zigzag silver chain structures were obtained from the reaction of newly synthesized tetra-ethynyl resorcin[4]­arenes with silver­(I) salts, which represents the successful example of the use of calixarene-based silver­(I)−ethynide supramolecular synthons to construct coordination frameworks.

Among the coinage metal complexes, the silver­(I)–ethynide synthon has been employed as a versatile building block to assemble silver­(I)-ethynide coordination networks and high-nuclearity clusters.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The study of coinage-metal (Cu, Ag, and Au) alkynyl complexes has received considerable interest for their diverse structures and potential as desirable precursors of rigid-rod molecular wires, nonlinear optical materials, and luminescent probes. Among the coinage metal complexes, the silver(I)-ethynide synthon has been employed as a versatile building block to assemble silver(I)-ethynide coordination networks and high-nuclearity clusters.

elements.content: In this regard, a systematic study was carried out on the assembly of Ag­(I) complexes containing variable ethynides, such as the all-carbon linear dianions, the R–CC– monoanions (R = aryl, heteroaryl, alkyl), and the only triethynide anion. Nevertheless, much less attention has been paid to the study of a silver­(I)–ethynide architecture based on the use of four ethynide groups attached to the same ligand skeleton. Generally, the direct increase of the number of ethynyl substituents on an aromatic nucleus will likely result in lower solubility in common solvents, which presents difficulty in crystallization of the corresponding silver­(I)–ethynide complexes. Recent employment of the attachment of flexible ethynyl groups to an aromatic skeleton via flexible -CH2–O- linkers provides a feasible way for constructing various silver­(I) coordination complexes with one, two, or three ethynide moieties.

Nevertheless, much less attention has been paid to the study of a silver(I)-ethynide architecture based on the use of four ethynide groups attached to the same ligand skeleton. Generally, the direct increase of the number of ethynyl substituents on an aromatic nucleus will likely result in lower solubility in common solvents, which presents difficulty in crystallization of the corresponding silver(I)-ethynide complexes. Recent employment of the attachment of flexible ethynyl groups to an aromatic skeleton via flexible -CH2-O- linkers provides a feasible way for constructing various silver(I) coordination complexes with one, two, or three ethynide moieties.

elements.content: Plentiful studies have indicated that the aggregation of silver­(I) atoms could be affected by the attachment of multiple rigid/flexible ethynyl ligands to a rigid molecular skeleton to produce remarkable silver­(I)–ethynide coordination networks as well as high-nuclearity clusters. Thus, far, studies employing alicyclic, aryl, and heteroaryl nuclei bearing multiple ethynyl substituents have been intensively pursued; however, the utilization of ethynide ligands tethered to a calixarene skeleton to assemble silver­(I)–ethynide complexes still remains unexplored. This prompted us to initiate an investigation of coordination framework assembly of calixarene-based multi-ethynide ligands with silver­(I) salts.

This prompted us to initiate an investigation of coordination framework assembly of calixarene-based multi-ethynide ligands with silver(I) salts.

elements.content: Calixarenes, as a special class of macrocyclic compounds along with crown-ethers, cyclodextrins, and curcurbiturils, have been widely studied because of their fascinating structure features and properties for potential applications. As the mainframe and/or rims of the calixarenes can be well modified with various kinds and number of substituents, they can function as versatile ligands. Of the substituted calixarene ligands, resorcin[4]­arenes are particularly attractive owing to their diversified structural features adjusted by various functionalized moieties. Therefore, it is anticipated that incorporation of the resorcin[4]­arene skeleton into the silver­(I)–ethynide system will present striking structural diversity as well as potential applications.

elements.content: Herein, we report the structural characterization of four novel tetra-ethynide silver­(I) complexes, namely, [Ag12(L1)2·(CH3CN)4·(NO3)4]·2H2O (1), [Ag4L1·(AgCF3CO2)4·(CH3OH)] (2), [Ag4L2·(AgCF3CO2)4]·H2O (3), and [Ag4L3·(AgCF3CO2)4]·0.75CH3COCH3 (4). Complex 1 exhibits a remarkable sandwich-type Ag12 cage embraced by two bowl-shaped tetra-anionic resorcin[4]­arene skeletons, while 2–4 show new silver­(I) chains each decorated on opposite sides by an alternating attachment of resorcin[4]­arene caps.

elements.content: In the experiment, all reagents were purchased commercially. FT-IR spectra were determined on a Mattson Alpha Centauri spectrometer. C and H contents were carried out on a PerkinElmer 240C elemental analyzer. Emission/excitation spectra in the solid-state were performed on a FLSP920 Edinburgh luminescence spectrometer. The electrochemical properties were investigated with a CHI660 electrochemical workstation. The Ag/AgCl (3 M KCl) electrode, Pt wire, and bulk-modified carbon-paste electrode (CPEs) were selected as the reference, counter, and working electrode, respectively. 1H NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker Avance 400 spectrometer. elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

In the experiment, all reagents were purchased commercially. FT-IR spectra were determined on a Mattson Alpha Centauri spectrometer. C and H contents were carried out on a PerkinElmer 240C elemental analyzer. Emission/excitation spectra in the solid-state were performed on a FLSP920 Edinburgh luminescence spectrometer. The electrochemical properties were investigated with a CHI660 electrochemical workstation. The Ag/AgCl (3 M KCl) electrode, Pt wire, and bulk-modified carbon-paste electrode (CPEs) were selected as the reference, counter, and working electrode, respectively. 1H NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker Avance 400 spectrometer. Mass spectra were determined on a Bruker AutoflexIII Smartbeam MS-spectrometer.

elements.content: The diffraction data were determined by using a Bruker Apex CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) for 1 and 2 at 293 K, and an Oxford Diffraction Gemini R Ultra diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) for 3 and 4 at 293 K, respectively. The crystallographic structures were solved by direct methods (SHELXS-97) and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 by SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package within WINGX. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically and hydrogen atoms of C were refined with U iso = 1.2U eq(C), d(C–H) = 0.93 Å for aromatic and U iso = 1.5U eq(C), d(C–H) = 0.97 Å for CH2. Crystallographic data are given in .

The related precursors L1′, L2′, and L3′ (Scheme S1) were synthesized by following the reported procedure. A mixture of L1′ (10.56 g, 1 mmol), acetonitrile (400 mL), propargyl bromide (9.52 g, 8 mmol), and K2CO3 (13.8 g, 100 mmol) was refluxed for 15 h. The mixture was filtrated to remove the K2CO3. After evaporation, ethanol solvent was added to the resulting product. The white precipitate of H4L1 was achieved in about 76% yield. Synthesis of Ag4L1

Triethylamine (2.8 mL, 2 mmol) and H4L1 (1.21 g, 1 mmol) were dissolved in CH3CN (40 mL) and stirred for a while. Then AgNO3 (0.68 g, 4 mmol) was poured into the above solution. Solid Ag4L1 was achieved in about 38% yield. The Ag4L2 and Ag4L3 were synthesized by a procedure similar to Ag4L1 in about 36% and 31% yields, respectively.

elements.content: Crystals of 1 were obtained in ca. 3% yield from reaction of Ag4L1 with AgNO3 in acetonitrile. X-ray crystallographic analysis established the formula of this crystalline complex 1 as [Ag12(L1)2·(CH3CN)4­·(NO3)4]­·2H2O (1), which crystallizes in space group I4/m (No. 87) with Z = 1. Tetra-anionic ligand L14– occupies Wyckoff position 4­(e) with site symmetry 4. Of the two silver­(I) atoms, Ag1 occupies a general equivalent position, while Ag2 lies on a crystallographic mirror plane. The C11C12 group in the μ3-η1,η2,η2 mode is capped by a Ag3 basket (Ag1, Ag1G, and Ag2G), with a Ag1G···C12 σ bond (Ag1G···C12 = 2.1696(2) Å), two Ag1···C11 and Ag2G···C11 π bonds (Ag1···C11 = 2.6554(3) Å and Ag2G···C11 = 2.7976(4) Å), and two Ag2G···C12 and Ag1···C12 mixed σ/π bonds (Ag2G···C12 = 2.3306(3) Å and Ag1···C12 = 2.1673(2) Å) (a). Interestingly, four symmetry-related Ag3 baskets are held together via Ag···Ag interactions varying from 3.0488(3) to 3.1655(3) Å, to give a Ag8 unit, which are then united together by sharing four Ag­(I) atoms (Ag2, Ag2E, Ag2F, Ag2G) to yield a remarkable Ag12 cage (b). Consequently, the L1 > Ag12 < L1 assembly exhibits the full point symmetry of the I4/m space group (c), with the Ag2 atom additionally coordinated by a bidentate chelating nitrate and an acetonitrile ligand (see Figure S1a). Moreover, the four arm-like ester groups on the L14– anion are free and located at the outside of the bowl-shaped resorcin[4]­arene units. The disordered lattice water molecules are included in the cavity formed by packing of adjacent sandwich-type Ag12 cages (Figure S1b).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Description of [Ag12(L1)2⋅(CH3CN)4⋅(NO3)4]⋅2H2O (1)

Crystals of 1 were obtained in ca. 3% yield from reaction of Ag4L1 with AgNO3 in acetonitrile. X-ray crystallographic analysis established the formula of this crystalline complex 1 as [Ag12(L1)2⋅(CH3CN)4⋅(NO3)4]⋅2H2O (1), which crystallizes in space group I4/m (No. 87) with Z = 1. Tetra-anionic ligand L14- occupies Wyckoff position 4(e) with site symmetry 4. Of the two silver(I) atoms, Ag1 occupies a general equivalent position, while Ag2 lies on a crystallographic mirror plane. The C11C12 group in the μ3-η1,η2,η2 mode is capped by a Ag3 basket (Ag1, Ag1G, and Ag2G), with a Ag1G⋅⋅⋅C12 σ bond (Ag1G⋅⋅⋅C12 = 2.1696(2) Å), two Ag1⋅⋅⋅C11 and Ag2G⋅⋅⋅C11 π bonds (Ag1⋅⋅⋅C11 = 2.6554(3) Å and Ag2G⋅⋅⋅C11 = 2.7976(4) Å), and two Ag2G⋅⋅⋅C12 and Ag1⋅⋅⋅C12 mixed σ/π bonds (Ag2G⋅⋅⋅C12 = 2.3306(3) Å and Ag1⋅⋅⋅C12 = 2.1673(2) Å) (a). Interestingly, four symmetry-related Ag3 baskets are held together via Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interactions varying from 3.0488(3) to 3.1655(3) Å, to give a Ag8 unit, which are then united together by sharing four Ag(I) atoms (Ag2, Ag2E, Ag2F, Ag2G) to yield a remarkable Ag12 cage (b). Consequently, the L1 > Ag12 < L1 assembly exhibits the full point symmetry of the I4/m space group (c), with the Ag2 atom additionally coordinated by a bidentate chelating nitrate and an acetonitrile ligand (see Figure S1a). Moreover, the four arm-like ester groups on the L14- anion are free and located at the outside of the bowl-shaped resorcin[4]arene units. The disordered lattice water molecules are included in the cavity formed by packing of adjacent sandwich-type Ag12 cages (Figure S1b).

(b) View of the central Ag12 cage exhibiting Ag···C and Ag···Ag bonds. (c) View of the sandwich-type Ag12 cage embraced by two bowl-shaped resorcin[4]­arene tetraethynide ligands. elements.content: Complex [Ag4L1·(AgCF3CO2)4­·(CH3OH)] 2 was achieved in a procedure analogous to that of 1, except that AgCF3CO2 and methanol were used in the reaction system. In the asymmetric unit of 2, there are one L14– anion, four trifluoroacetate anions, eight silver­(I) cations, and one coordination methanol molecule. Four ethynide anions on the L14– anion exhibit distinct coordination fashions (a). The C48C49 and C63C64 moieties, exhibiting μ3-η1,η2,η2 and μ3-η1,η1,η2 fashions, respectively, are each capped by a Ag3 basket with Ag···C bonds. The other two C1C2 and C30C31 ethynide terminals in the μ4-η1,η1,η1,η2 manner are each linked to a Ag4 unit, forming σ, mixed σ/π and π bonds. It is noteworthy that one phenyl carbon atom (C26) on the L14– anion coordinates to Ag7 with bond distance of 2.8115(1) Å, indicating the presence of silver­(I)-π interaction. Moreover, two methoxy ester groups on the L14– anion are involved in coordination with silver­(I) atoms (Ag7–O17 = 2.5292(1), Ag2–O19 = 2.7110(1), Ag8–O10 = 2.8512(2), and Ag8–O11 = 2.6158(1) Å), stabilizing the silver­(I) clusters, while the remaining two ester groups are free.

elements.content: As illustrated in b, two Ag3 baskets, which are composed of Ag1A, Ag4A and Ag5A, and Ag1, Ag4A and Ag8, respectively, share the Ag4A to engender a Ag5 aggregate. Likewise, two Ag4 baskets (Ag3, Ag3A, Ag6, Ag7; Ag2, Ag5, Ag6, Ag7) are joined together by sharing the Ag6 and Ag7 to form a Ag7 aggregate. Such Ag5 and Ag7 aggregates are further associated via argentophilic Ag1···Ag2 and Ag1···Ag5 interactions to produce a Ag­(I) chain, which are stabilized by the coordinated CF3COO– groups (c). It is interesting to note that the infinite Ag­(I) chain is sandwiched by the bowl-shaped resorcin[4]­arene units in pairs via Ag···C interactions (c). Additionally, adjacent Ag­(I) chains are packed in an intersected manner (Figure S2). The structure analyses of 1 and 2 indicate that the silver­(I) salts used in the reaction system (AgNO3 and AgCF3CO2) play a dominant role in silver­(I)–ethynide supramolecular synthon assembly.

elements.content: To evaluate the effect of substituents on the silver­(I)–ethynide supramolecular synthons, a new resorcin[4]­arene-based ethynide ligand H4L2 with substituted −O–CH3 groups is assembled with silver­(I) to give complex [Ag4L2·(AgCF3CO2)4]·H2O 3. In 3, the ethynide moieties, C32C33 and C47C48, each adopts the μ3-η1,η1,η2 mode and is capped by a Ag3 basket, with Ag···C π, σ, and mixed σ/π bonds (a). The other two ethynide terminals, C1C2 and C63C64, exhibit μ4-η1,η1,η2,η2 and μ4-η1,η1,η1,η2 modes, respectively, and are each linked to a Ag4 basket to yield Ag···C bonds. Notably, dramatically different from those observed in 1 and 2, three phenyl carbon atoms (C5, C60, C61) are involved in coordination with the silver­(I) atoms in 3. Atom C5 coordinates to Ag1 with the Ag1···C5 distance of 2.4575(1) Å, and atoms C60 and C61 bridge Ag7 atom in the μ-η2 mode with Ag7···C60 and Ag7···C61 distances of 2.7913(1) and 2.6723(1) Å, respectively. Moreover, four −O–CH3 groups on the L24– anion are free, and located at the outside of the bowl-shaped resorcin[4]­arene. The ordered lattice water molecule is located in the cavity surrounded by four n-amyl moieties of the bowl-shaped resorcin[4]­arene.

Structural Description of [Ag4L2⋅(AgCF3CO2)4]⋅H2O (3)

To evaluate the effect of substituents on the silver(I)-ethynide supramolecular synthons, a new resorcin[4]arene-based ethynide ligand H4L2 with substituted -O-CH3 groups is assembled with silver(I) to give complex [Ag4L2⋅(AgCF3CO2)4]⋅H2O 3. In 3, the ethynide moieties, C32C33 and C47C48, each adopts the μ3-η1,η1,η2 mode and is capped by a Ag3 basket, with Ag⋅⋅⋅C π, σ, and mixed σ/π bonds (a). The other two ethynide terminals, C1C2 and C63C64, exhibit μ4-η1,η1,η2,η2 and μ4-η1,η1,η1,η2 modes, respectively, and are each linked to a Ag4 basket to yield Ag⋅⋅⋅C bonds. Notably, dramatically different from those observed in 1 and 2, three phenyl carbon atoms (C5, C60, C61) are involved in coordination with the silver(I) atoms in 3. Atom C5 coordinates to Ag1 with the Ag1⋅⋅⋅C5 distance of 2.4575(1) Å, and atoms C60 and C61 bridge Ag7 atom in the μ-η2 mode with Ag7⋅⋅⋅C60 and Ag7⋅⋅⋅C61 distances of 2.7913(1) and 2.6723(1) Å, respectively. Moreover, four -O-CH3 groups on the L24- anion are free, and located at the outside of the bowl-shaped resorcin[4]arene. The ordered lattice water molecule is located in the cavity surrounded by four n-amyl moieties of the bowl-shaped resorcin[4]arene.

elements.content: As shown in b, two adjacent Ag3 baskets are fused together by edge sharing Ag2 and Ag8B to produce a Ag5 aggregate. Likewise, by sharing Ag6 and Ag7 atoms, two Ag4 clusters coalesce to form an irregular Ag7 aggregate. Such Ag5 and Ag7 aggregates are associated through sharing Ag1 atom to give a Ag11 aggregate, which are further held together via Ag­(I)···Ag­(I) interactions to generate a different Ag­(I) chain. This Ag­(I) chain is consolidated by the surrounding CF3COO– anions (c). Moreover, the bowl-shaped resorcin[4]­arenes are alternately decorated on two sides of the Ag­(I) chain. Adjacent Ag­(I) chains are packed in parallel orientation. Apparently, such silver­(I) chain is quite different from that observed in 2, which probably accounts for the variable substituents from −COOCH3 to −O–CH3 groups on the resorcin[4]­arenes as well as the differently associated Ag­(I)-π interactions from aromatics.

This Ag(I) chain is consolidated by the surrounding CF3COO- anions (c). Moreover, the bowl-shaped resorcin[4]arenes are alternately decorated on two sides of the Ag(I) chain. Adjacent Ag(I) chains are packed in parallel orientation. Apparently, such silver(I) chain is quite different from that observed in 2, which probably accounts for the variable substituents from -COOCH3 to -O-CH3 groups on the resorcin[4]arenes as well as the differently associated Ag(I)-π interactions from aromatics.

elements.content: Complex [Ag4L3·(AgCF3CO2)4]­·0.75CH3COCH3 4 was achieved in a procedure similar to 3 by changing the alkyl groups attached to the resorcin[4]­arene skeleton. Crystallographic analysis demonstrates that 4 is a structural analogue of 3, but the ethynide coordination modes are different between 3 and 4 (). In 4, the C29C30 and C41C42 are each capped by a Ag3 unit in the μ3-η1,η1,η2 manner, whereas C50C51 and C17C18 exhibit μ4-η1,η1,η2,η2 and μ4-η1,η1,η1,η2 fashions, respectively (a and S3). Additionally, the Ag­(I)-π interactions are drastically different between 3 and 4. In 4 the carbon atoms C1 and C2 on the phenyl group coordinate to Ag3 in the μ–η2 mode (Ag3···C1 = 2.4877(3) Å and Ag3···C2 = 2.8684(4) Å), and C14 and C15 atoms bridge Ag5 atom in the same μ-η2 manner (Ag5···C14 = 2.7169(4) Å and Ag5···C15 = 2.7952(4) Å). Moreover, atom O7 from the −O–CH3 group coordinates to the Ag5 atom with Ag5–O7 bond length of 2.6220(3) Å. Notably, the lattice acetone molecule occupying the cavity surrounded by four propyl moieties was found to be disordered with fractional site occupancy (b). Clearly, the different Ag­(I)···C and Ag­(I)-π interactions between 3 and 4 are mainly ascribed to the variation of the alkyl groups attached to the resorcin[4]­arene units.

Structural Description of [Ag4L3⋅(AgCF3CO2)4]⋅0.75CH3COCH3 (4)

Complex [Ag4L3⋅(AgCF3CO2)4]⋅0.75CH3COCH3 4 was achieved in a procedure similar to 3 by changing the alkyl groups attached to the resorcin[4]arene skeleton. Crystallographic analysis demonstrates that 4 is a structural analogue of 3, but the ethynide coordination modes are different between 3 and 4 (). In 4, the C29C30 and C41C42 are each capped by a Ag3 unit in the μ3-η1,η1,η2 manner, whereas C50C51 and C17C18 exhibit μ4-η1,η1,η2,η2 and μ4-η1,η1,η1,η2 fashions, respectively (a and S3). Additionally, the Ag(I)-π interactions are drastically different between 3 and 4. In 4 the carbon atoms C1 and C2 on the phenyl group coordinate to Ag3 in the μ-η2 mode (Ag3⋅⋅⋅C1 = 2.4877(3) Å and Ag3⋅⋅⋅C2 = 2.8684(4) Å), and C14 and C15 atoms bridge Ag5 atom in the same μ-η2 manner (Ag5⋅⋅⋅C14 = 2.7169(4) Å and Ag5⋅⋅⋅C15 = 2.7952(4) Å). Moreover, atom O7 from the -O-CH3 group coordinates to the Ag5 atom with Ag5-O7 bond length of 2.6220(3) Å. Notably, the lattice acetone molecule occupying the cavity surrounded by four propyl moieties was found to be disordered with fractional site occupancy (b). Clearly, the different Ag(I)⋅⋅⋅C and Ag(I)-π interactions between 3 and 4 are mainly ascribed to the variation of the alkyl groups attached to the resorcin[4]arene units.

elements.content: We have prepared and structurally characterized a new family of silver­(I)–ethynide supramolecular synthons employing the newly designed tetra-ethynide functionalized resorcin[4]­arenes. The calixarene-based ethynide ligands were successfully used to assemble silver­(I)–ethynide supramolecular networks. Complex 1 represents an unusual sandwich-type Ag12 cage embraced by two bowl-shaped resorcin[4]­arene units. Complexes 2–4 provide a new example of silver­(I) chains decorated by an alternating attachment of bowl-shaped resorcin[4]­arene units.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have prepared and structurally characterized a new family of silver(I)-ethynide supramolecular synthons employing the newly designed tetra-ethynide functionalized resorcin[4]arenes. The calixarene-based ethynide ligands were successfully used to assemble silver(I)-ethynide supramolecular networks. Complex 1 represents an unusual sandwich-type Ag12 cage embraced by two bowl-shaped resorcin[4]arene units. Complexes 2-4 provide a new example of silver(I) chains decorated by an alternating attachment of bowl-shaped resorcin[4]arene units.

The related precursors L1′, L2′, and L3′ (Scheme S1) were synthesized by following the reported procedure. A mixture of L1′ (10.56 g, 1 mmol), acetonitrile (400 mL), propargyl bromide (9.52 g, 8 mmol), and K2CO3 (13.8 g, 100 mmol) was refluxed for 15 h. The mixture was filtrated to remove the K2CO3. After evaporation, ethanol solvent was added to the resulting product. The white precipitate of H4L1 was achieved in about 76% yield. The H4L2 and H4L3 were also synthesized by a similar procedure to H4L1 in about 72% and 69% yields, respectively. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) for H4L1: δ 6.63 (s, 4H), 6.45 (s, 4H), 4.54 (t, 4H), 4.42–4.24 (m, 16H), 3.77 (s, 12H), 2.4­(s, 4H), 1.83–1.82 (m, 8H), 1.37–1.28 (m, 24H), 0.86 (t, 12H); [M + H]+: 1209.5822, found: 1209.4595. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) for H4L2: δ 6.61 (s, 4H), 6.5 (s, 4H), 4.49 (t, 4H), 4.21 (s, 8H), 3.64 (s, 12H), 1.82–1.80 (m, 8H), 1.33–1.28 (m, 24H), 0.86 (t, 12H); [M + H]+: 977.5712, found: 977.3152. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) for H4L3: δ 6.64 (s, 4H), 6.51 (s, 4H), 4.42 (t, 4H), 4.21 (s, 8H), 3.64 (s, 12H), 2.46 (t, 4H), 1.89–1.82 (m, 8H), 0.90 (t, 12H); [M + H]+: 809.3899, found: 808.9962.

Synthesis of Ag<sub>4</sub>L1

Triethylamine (2.8 mL, 2 mmol) and H4L1 (1.21 g, 1 mmol) were dissolved in CH3CN (40 mL) and stirred for a while. Then AgNO3 (0.68 g, 4 mmol) was poured into the above solution. Solid Ag4L1 was achieved in about 38% yield. The Ag4L2 and Ag4L3 were synthesized by a procedure similar to Ag4L1 in about 36% and 31% yields, respectively.

Synthesis of [Ag<sub>12</sub>(L1)<sub>2</sub>·(CH<sub>3</sub>CN)<sub>4</sub>­·(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>4</sub>]­·2H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

Moist Ag4L1 (∼0.10 g) was added to the acetonitrile (3 mL) of AgNO3 (0.34 g, 2 mmol). The mixture was filtered after stirring for additional 5 min. Crystals were achieved at ambient temperature after 1 week in about 3% yield. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 2008 cm–1 (w, νCC); Anal. Calcd (%) for C304H368Ag24N16O92 (M r = 8307.02): C 43.95, H 4.47. Found: C 43.89, H 4.33.

Synthesis of [Ag<sub>4</sub>L1·(AgCF<sub>3</sub>CO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>4</sub>­·(CH<sub>3</sub>OH)] (<bold>2</bold>)

Compound 2 was synthesized by a procedure similar to that of 1 with AgCF3CO2 and methanol instead of AgNO3 and acetonitrile in about 3% yield. (KBr pellet, cm–1): 2025 cm–1 (w, νCC); Anal. Calcd (%) for C81H83Ag8F12O25 (M r = 2547.43): C 38.19, H 3.28. Found: C 38.42, H 3.53.

Synthesis of [Ag<sub>4</sub>L2·(AgCF<sub>3</sub>CO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>4</sub>]­·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>)

Moist Ag4L2 (∼0.10 g) was added to acetone (3 mL) of AgBF4 (0.190 g, 1 mmol) and AgCF3CO2 (0.15 g, 1 mmol). After being stirred for an additional 5 min, the mixture was filtered. Colorless crystals of 3 were achieved at ambient temperature after 1 week in about 16% yield. (KBr pellet, cm–1): 2041 cm–1 (w, νCC); Anal. Calcd (%) for C72H78Ag8F12O17 (M r = 2306.30): C 37.50, H 3.40. Found: C 37.29, H 3.61.

Synthesis of [Ag<sub>4</sub>L3·(AgCF<sub>3</sub>CO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>4</sub>]­·0.75CH<sub>3</sub>COCH<sub>3</sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

Compound 4 was synthesized by the similar procedure to 3. During the synthesis of 4, Ag4L3 was utilized instead of Ag4L2. Crystals were achieved in about 4% yield. (KBr pellet, cm–1): 2041 cm–1 (w, νCC); Anal. Calcd (%) for C62.25H56.50Ag8F12O16.75 (M r = 2163.53): C 34.56, H 2.63. Found: C 34.81, H 2.42.

The H4L2 and H4L3 were also synthesized by a similar procedure to H4L1 in about 72% and 69% yields, respectively. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) for H4L1: δ 6.63 (s, 4H), 6.45 (s, 4H), 4.54 (t, 4H), 4.42-4.24 (m, 16H), 3.77 (s, 12H), 2.4(s, 4H), 1.83-1.82 (m, 8H), 1.37-1.28 (m, 24H), 0.86 (t, 12H); [M + H]+: 1209.5822, found: 1209.4595. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) for H4L2: δ 6.61 (s, 4H), 6.5 (s, 4H), 4.49 (t, 4H), 4.21 (s, 8H), 3.64 (s, 12H), 1.82-1.80 (m, 8H), 1.33-1.28 (m, 24H), 0.86 (t, 12H); [M + H]+: 977.5712, found: 977.3152. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) for H4L3: δ 6.64 (s, 4H), 6.51 (s, 4H), 4.42 (t, 4H), 4.21 (s, 8H), 3.64 (s, 12H), 2.46 (t, 4H), 1.89-1.82 (m, 8H), 0.90 (t, 12H); [M + H]+: 809.3899, found: 808.9962.

Synthesis of Ag4L1

Triethylamine (2.8 mL, 2 mmol) and H4L1 (1.21 g, 1 mmol) were dissolved in CH3CN (40 mL) and stirred for a while. Then AgNO3 (0.68 g, 4 mmol) was poured into the above solution. Solid Ag4L1 was achieved in about 38% yield. The Ag4L2 and Ag4L3 were synthesized by a procedure similar to Ag4L1 in about 36% and 31% yields, respectively.

Synthesis of [Ag12(L1)2⋅(CH3CN)4⋅(NO3)4]⋅2H2O (1)

Moist Ag4L1 (~0.10 g) was added to the acetonitrile (3 mL) of AgNO3 (0.34 g, 2 mmol). The mixture was filtered after stirring for additional 5 min. Crystals were achieved at ambient temperature after 1 week in about 3% yield. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 2008 cm-1 (w, νCC); Anal. Calcd (%) for C304H368Ag24N16O92 (M r = 8307.02): C 43.95, H 4.47. Found: C 43.89, H 4.33.

Synthesis of [Ag4L1⋅(AgCF3CO2)4⋅(CH3OH)] (2)

Compound 2 was synthesized by a procedure similar to that of 1 with AgCF3CO2 and methanol instead of AgNO3 and acetonitrile in about 3% yield. (KBr pellet, cm-1): 2025 cm-1 (w, νCC); Anal. Calcd (%) for C81H83Ag8F12O25 (M r = 2547.43): C 38.19, H 3.28. Found: C 38.42, H 3.53.

Synthesis of [Ag4L2⋅(AgCF3CO2)4]⋅H2O (3)

Moist Ag4L2 (~0.10 g) was added to acetone (3 mL) of AgBF4 (0.190 g, 1 mmol) and AgCF3CO2 (0.15 g, 1 mmol). After being stirred for an additional 5 min, the mixture was filtered. Colorless crystals of 3 were achieved at ambient temperature after 1 week in about 16% yield. (KBr pellet, cm-1): 2041 cm-1 (w, νCC); Anal. Calcd (%) for C72H78Ag8F12O17 (M r = 2306.30): C 37.50, H 3.40. Found: C 37.29, H 3.61.

Synthesis of [Ag4L3⋅(AgCF3CO2)4]⋅0.75CH3COCH3 (4)

Compound 4 was synthesized by the similar procedure to 3. During the synthesis of 4, Ag4L3 was utilized instead of Ag4L2. Crystals were achieved in about 4% yield. (KBr pellet, cm-1): 2041 cm-1 (w, νCC); Anal. Calcd (%) for C62.25H56.50Ag8F12O16.75 (M r = 2163.53): C 34.56, H 2.63. Found: C 34.81, H 2.42.
